column1: It is very common for people to think that the brain controls all of the movements that we make. When we think about moving
column2: signals travel from the brain travel down to the spinal cord through nerves (almost like telephone wires). The spinal cord acts like a freeway with many exits in both directions. In one direction
column3: information from the senses travels to the brain
column5: signals are carried from the brain to control the muscles. The actions of these muscles are what cause the arms and legs to move. However
column6: the brain is not always required to cause movement. By examining animals
column7: scientists discovered that complex groups of cells within the spinal cord can control walking. It turns out that the main job of controlling walking is done by the spinal cord
